texts.value: Glycoprotein N and glycoprotein C interact with each other and are present at the surface of the virion (Probable). Glycoprotein N probably locks the Gn-Gc complex in a prefusion state (PubMed:34793197). Glycoprotein N and glycoprotein C are able to attach the virion to host cell receptors (Probable). This attachment induces virion internalization predominantly through clathrin-dependent endocytosis (PubMed:19088291)

Glycoprotein C and glycoprotein N interact with each other and are present at the surface of the virion (PubMed:19088291). The spikes at the surface of the virion are formed by an N-terminal extension of glycoprotein C (By similarity). Glycoprotein N and glycoprotein C are able to attach the virion to host cell receptors (Probable). This attachment induces virion internalization predominantly through clathrin-dependent endocytosis (PubMed:19088291). Class II fusion protein that promotes fusion of viral membrane with host endosomal membrane after endocytosis of the virion (PubMed:34793197, PubMed:35234630). Exposure of the glycoprotein spikes to potassium is necessary for the conformational change leading to fusion (By similarity)
Heterodimer with glycoprotein C; in prefusion state
Heterodimer with glycoprotein N; in prefusion state (PubMed:34793197). Homotrimeric; in postfusion state (PubMed:34793197, PubMed:35234630)
Interaction between glycoprotein C and glycoprotein N is essential for proper targeting of glycoprotein C to the Golgi complex, where virion budding occurs

Specific enzymatic cleavage by host MBTPS1/S1P/SKI-1 endopeptidase yield glycoprotein N (PubMed:17898072, PubMed:25933376, PubMed:12885882). Specific enzymatic cleavages by host furin-like protease and MBTPS1/S1P endopeptidase yield GP38 (PubMed:25933376)
Belongs to the nairovirus envelope glycoprotein family

citation.title: Characterization of the glycoproteins of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus.
Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus glycoprotein proteolytic processing by subtilase SKI-1.
Intracellular localization of Crimean-Congo Hemorrhagic Fever (CCHF) virus glycoproteins.
Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus glycoprotein processing by the endoprotease SKI-1/S1P is critical for virus infectivity.
Identification of a novel C-terminal cleavage of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus PreGN that leads to generation of an NSM protein.
N-linked glycosylation of Gn (but not Gc) is important for Crimean Congo hemorrhagic fever virus glycoprotein localization and transport.
